document.docAuthor: Barros, Lydia Vieira De, Santos, George Garcia & Pinheiro, Ulisses
document.docTitle: Clathria (Clathria) nicoleae Barros, Santos & Pinheiro, 2013, sp. nov.
document.masterDocTitle: Clathria (Clathria) Schmidt, 1862 from Brazil with description of a new species and a review of records (Poecilosclerida: Demospongiae: Porifera)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Clathria (Clathria) Schmidt, 1862 from Brazil with description of a new species and a review of records (Poecilosclerida: Demospongiae: Porifera)

subSubSection.paragraph:
(
Figs 1–4
;
Tables 1
–2)

Synonymy :
Clathria
(
Clathria
) sp. (Muricy et al. 2008 : pp. 156 ).

Type locality:
Brazil , Rio Grande do Norte State, Bacia Potiguar (lat.
04º 51 ’ 26.6 ’’S
; long.
36 º07’04.8’’W
).

Diagnosis.
Clathria ( Clathria ) nicoleae
sp. nov.
is the only
Clathria
(
Clathria
) in Atlantic with auxiliary tylostrongyles, principal styles, auxiliary subtylostyles, accessory acanthostyles as megascleras; toxas and palmate isochelae as microscleres.

External morphology (
Figs. 2–3
). Ficiform or erect palmate, sideways flattened resembling a fan, 4 to 30 cm high and 1 to 8 cm wide. Color in situ is orange to reddish but after fixation it turns to a brownish-cream, rugose surface to honeycombed and reticulated. The biggest oscules are concentrated at the tip, even though some smaller ones are found laterally with superficial channels gathering around them (
Fig. 3
B). It also shows channels with a star-like pattern, which are very characteristic (see
Fig. 3
C).

Skeleton (
Fig. 3
D–F). Plumoreticulated with abundant spongin fibers and styles accompanying them. Ectosome can be distinguished from choanosome because of superficial styles, and also because of the presence of tangential auxiliary tylostrongyles (
Fig. 3
E), which are not seen presenting this formation elsewhere. It has disorganized ectosomal skeleton with bouquets of styles, and echinating acanthostyles and subtylostyles can be found along many channels (
Fig. 3
F). Microscleres are diffusely distributed.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 2.
Clathria ( Clathria ) nicoleae
sp. nov.
in situ in northeast Brazil. A–B, specimens in the Paraíba State; C–D, specimens in the Rio Grande do Norte State.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Spicules (
Fig. 4
A–I). Megascleres . Principal styles (
Fig. 4
A–B), thick, slightly curved, smooth (
108- 182.3
- 273 /
2.4- 11.8
- 33 μm). Auxiliary subtylostyles (
Fig. 4
C–D), straight, thin, lengthy, smooth, with microspined base (
210- 257.6
- 312 /
2.4- 3.7
- 6 μm). Auxiliary tylostrongyles (
Fig. 4
E–F), straight, body (shaft) smooth, with slightly different microspined extremities (curves spines), varying from tylostyles to asymmetric strongyles (
99- 173.4
- 285 / 1.0-
2.8 -5.4
μm). Accessory acanthostyles (
Fig. 4
G–H), small, thin, with microspined base (blunt verrucose to pointy thorns) and the extreme part of the spicule microspined as well (hook-shaped spines) (
60- 89.4
- 121 /
1- 3.2
- 6 μm). Microscleres . Toxas (
Fig. 4
J), rare, smooth, accentuated curvature in most cases, varying to less curved ones (
19- 40.8
- 84 μm). Palmate isochelae (
Fig.
4
I), smooth, normal form, abundant and relatively large in size (
14.3- 18.6
- 24 μm).
Etymology. The name of the species honours Nicole Boury-Esnault for her grand contribution in the field of sponge taxonomy.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 3.
Clathria ( Clathria ) nicoleae
sp. nov.
(UFPEPOR 208, holotype). A, preserved specimen; B, oscules on lateral side; C, channels in standard star-like surface; D, thick section showing the ectosome and choanosome; E, detail of thick section showing the thin ectosome with some tylostrongyles tangential (arrows); F, details of the two channels showing echinating spicules. Scale bars: A = 5 cm; B = 1 cm; C = 1,5 cm; D = 200 μm; E = 150 μm; F = 100 μm.

FIGURE 4. Spicule composition of
Clathria ( Clathria ) nicoleae
sp. nov.
(UFPEPOR 208, holotype) in SEM. A–B, principal styles and details of ends; C–D, auxiliary subtylostyles and details of ends; E–F, auxiliary tylostrongyle and details of ends; G– H, accessory acanthostyles and details of end; I, palmate isochelae; J, toxa. Scale bars: A = 20 μm; B = 10 μm; C = 50 μm; D = 2,5 μm; E = 12 μm; F = 2 μm; G = 10 μm; H = 2,5 μm; I = 3,5 μm; J = 10 μm.

TABLE 1. Comparison of spicule dimensions (μm) among specimens of
Clathria ( Clathria ) nicoleae
sp. nov.
collected in Basin Potiguar (RN) and João Pessoa (PB). Values are in micrometres (μm) and n=30.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Remarks. Although there are 25 valid species of
Clathria
(
Clathria
) in the Atlantic Ocean,
Clathria
( C. )
nicoleae
sp. nov.
is the only one that has auxiliary tylostrongyles. The species that are most similar in external morphology with the new species are: C. ( C. )
oculata Cuartas, 1992
; C. ( C. )
prolifera (Ellis & Solander, 1786 )
and C. ( C .)
unica Cuartas, 1992
. However they don’t have auxiliary tylostrongyles and the others spicules differ in size (see Table 2 ). In Brazilian Coast
Clathria
( C. )
nicoleae
sp. nov.
differs from C. ( C .)
calypso Boury-Esnault, 1973
because of the presence of auxiliary tylostrongyles and absence of two categories of auxiliary subtylostyles and two categories of toxas (see Table 2 ). Besides that,
Clathria
( C .)
nicoleae
sp. nov.
shows palmate isochelae with dimensions far greater than any other
Clathria
(
Clathria
) from Atlantic Ocean (see Table 2 ).

Clathria ( Clathria ) calypso
Boury-Esnault, 1973
(
Fig. 5–6
; Table 2 )

Clathria calypso Boury-Esnault 1973
, p. 286 ; Hechtel 1976 , p. 253 .
Clathria ( Clathria ) calypso
; Muricy et al . 2011 , p. 146 .

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 5.
Clathria ( Clathria ) calypso Boury-Esnault, 1973
(MNHN.LBIM.D.NBE 1035, holotype). A, specimen preserved; B, thick section showing the ectosome and choanosome; C, details of the fibers with echinating spicules. Scale bars: A = 1 cm; B = 500 μm; C = 100 μm.

FIGURE 6. Spicule composition of
Clathria ( Clathria ) calypso Boury-Esnault, 1973
(MNHN.LBIM.D.NBE 1035). A, principal styles; B, auxiliary subtylostyles I; C, auxiliary subtylostyles II; D–F, details of respectively A–C; G, accessory acanthostyles; H, toxas I; I, toxas II; J, palmate isochelae. Scale bars: A–B = 100 μm; C = 50 μm; D = 8 μm; E = 3 μm; F = 1 μm; G = 20 μm; H = 150 μm; I = 30 μm; J = 6 μm.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Type specimens:
Holotype—MNHN.LBIM.D.NBE 1035,
16º 47 ’S
–
38 º 53 ’W
, Corumbau District, 27 m , Calypso sta. 76 expedition, det. N. Boury-Esnault.

Redescription: External morphology (
Fig. 5
A). Ramified sponge, brown-purplish, 4 cm height, surface is hispid with thin, tangencial peel, clear detachable. Oscules can be seen at the tip of each small branch.

Skeleton (
Fig. 5
B–C). Ectosome with auxiliary styles forming bouquets. Choanosome plumoreticulated containing well developed spongin fibers with principal styles and echinating acanthostyles. Fibres may form a polygonal matrix. Palmate isochelae seemingly randomly dispersed.

Spicules (
Fig. 6
A–I). Megascleres . Principal styles (
Fig. 6
A) smooth and stout, varying from straight to slightly curved (
246- 312.5
- 387 /
10- 13.8
- 16 μm). Auxiliary subtylostyles I (
Fig. 6
B), normally straight, smooth, lengthy and with a poorly defined base (
267- 312
- 351 /
3- 5
- 6 μm). Auxiliary subtylostyles II (
Fig. 6
C), smooth, thin, varying from straight to curved and with a slightly bulbous base (
90- 118.9
- 141 /
1.5- 2.4
- 3 μm). Accessory acanthostyles (
Fig. 6
G), straight, some with a flattened base, irregularly acanthose, straight or bent spines, curved spines concentrated in the median (
57- 62.4
- 69 /
5.1- 5.8
- 6 μm). Microscleres . Toxas I (‘accolada’- type ) (
Fig. 6
H), rare, not observed in SEM, long, thin, slightly curved in the middle and with straight endings (
321- 432
- 522 / 1 μm). Toxas II (
Fig.
6
I), are longer, thin, strongly curved and some with extremities slightly lifted (
108- 142.6
- 216 / 1.5 μm). Palmate isochelae (
Fig. 6
J), rather narrow, but otherwise of quite usual shape, very little size variation and abundant (
10- 11.7
- 13.5 μm).
Distribution. Corumbau District, Bahia State, Brazil .

Remarks. In the process of redescribing this species it was noticed an additional spicules category. Spicular nomeclature was used as it is found in Hooper ( 1996 ). The auxiliary styles described by Boury-Esnault ( 1973 ) were divided into two categories of auxiliary subtylostyles varying size and shape (
Figure 6
B–C, Table 2 ). Beside this, it was observed that some spicules dimensions were different from the ones in the original description (see Table 2 ). It was noted, as well, that toxas I were much more rare and toxas II had a wide range of sizes and shapes (
Figure 6
H–I).
